reinforcements.relationship: Direct reinforcement. The library's single-sum principle (show one total in the user's native format before any breakdown) is the host-side expression of the same insight. works-001 applies the identical principle to the guest side: show the gain vs. reference before the absolute price. Both are grounded in Kahneman's bat-and-ball finding that people fail at simple arithmetic when an intuitive but wrong answer is available. The pricing format mismatch is now confirmed from THREE independent lenses: host-side (andreas-call), guest-side (nneka-call), and guest-side (Steve Zhang call). This is the strongest convergence signal in the library.
reinforcements.combined_strength: Very high. Three independent validations of the same pricing architecture principle across both sides of the marketplace.

reinforcements.library_element: works-001 (System 1 Trust Gate at Every Phase Transition)
reinforcements.relationship: Extends the System 1 trust gate from phase transitions (library) to commitment escalation points (this run). The library element prescribes visual consistency and familiar language at phase boundaries. works-003 prescribes certainty delivery at commitment points within phases. Together they establish a complete continuity-and-certainty framework: System 1 continuity across phases (library) and System 2 certainty within phases (this run).
reinforcements.combined_strength: High. Different Kahneman frameworks (System 1/2 from Part 1, Certainty Effect from Part 4) converging on the same UX problem.

reinforcements.relationship: The library's single-sum hierarchy (total > conversion > breakdown) and this run's gain-frame hierarchy (reference gain > monthly total > nightly rate) are compatible and complementary. The library addresses the host's mental model (monthly rent). This run addresses the guest's mental model (savings vs. alternative). Both eliminate the same problem: forcing System 2 arithmetic on users who think in different units than the platform displays.
reinforcements.combined_strength: Very high. The two hierarchies can be unified into a single pricing architecture that works for both sides of the marketplace.

reinforcements.relationship: The library's depletion-aware design (smart defaults, save-and-resume, fewer decisions per step) aligns with the accelerated funnel's compression of the search-evaluate-propose flow. Loss-state guests are a specific case of depleted users: they are depleted not from prior platform tasks but from their life situation. The accelerated funnel applies the library's depletion principles to a situation-specific context.
reinforcements.combined_strength: High. Extends depletion-aware design from platform-induced depletion to life-situation-induced depletion.

reinforcements.relationship: The library's trust credential stack (mechanism before claim) and this run's protection shield (verified host, photo guarantee, payment protected, cancel coverage) follow the same trust-building principle. The library applies it to the host side (credit checks, vetting, pre-authorization). This run applies it to the guest side (host verification, photo accuracy, escrow, cancellation coverage). Both prescribe process-before-promise information architecture.
reinforcements.combined_strength: High. Trust architecture now covers both sides of the marketplace with the same structural pattern.

reinforcements.relationship: The library's advisor-moment pattern (solicit expertise to lock commitment) and this run's satisfaction protection (savings pulse, proactive shield, renewal bridge) both serve retention during the active phase. The library activates commitment through identity (advisor mode). This run protects commitment through continuous positive reinforcement (savings visibility). Together they create a dual-mechanism retention system: identity-based commitment (host side) and value-based commitment (guest side).
reinforcements.combined_strength: Medium. Different mechanisms but both target retention during the active phase.

contradictions.this_run_element: looks-001 (Gain-Frame Price Display) introduces --gain-green (#0D9488) for savings badges
contradictions.library_element: Style guide protocol tokens specify NO GREEN, NO YELLOW
contradictions.nature: The --gain-green color (#0D9488) introduced in looks-001 contradicts the protocol token rule of 'NO GREEN, NO YELLOW.' However, this rule applies specifically to protocol components (popup replication), not to all platform elements. The gain-green is justified for savings/financial-outcome displays that are distinct from protocol components.
contradictions.resolution: Accepted with constraint. The --gain-green color is permitted ONLY for financial-outcome displays (savings badges, savings dashboard) and NEVER for protocol components, status indicators, or general UI elements. Document this scope explicitly in the token system. The library's production tokens.json uses warm green (#2d5a3d) as an accent, but the style guide uses purple -- this run introduces a third color system for financial gains only.

contradictions.this_run_element: communicates-005 (Rare-Event Defusal) suggests addressing top 3-4 guest fears
contradictions.library_element: communicates-003 (Trust Credential Stack) limits trust signals to 3 per screen
contradictions.nature: Minor tension: the rare-event defusal module shows 4 protection items, while the trust credential stack limits trust signals to 3 per screen. The defusal module treats protection as a different category than trust credentials (protection = what if things go wrong; credentials = why things will go right). Four protection items (verified host, photo guarantee, payment protected, cancel coverage) are all four distinct concern categories.
contradictions.resolution: Accepted. The 3-signal limit applies to trust credentials (process-before-promise verification signals). The 4-item protection module is a different pattern (fear defusal, not trust building). Both can coexist on the same page as long as they serve different cognitive functions. Document the distinction.

extensions.extension_to: The entire library's approach to pre-commitment engagement
extensions.description: No existing library element addresses the deliberate acceleration of mental ownership before commitment. The library focuses on reducing friction (depletion, speed-matching) and building trust (credential stacks). works-004 introduces a new category: psychological ownership engineering. The 'Plan Your Stay' configurator and 'Your Space' preview card are not friction-reducers or trust-builders -- they are ownership accelerators that use Kahneman's endowment effect to make non-submission feel like a loss. This extends the library's pre-commitment toolkit from 'make it easy' to 'make leaving feel expensive.'

The library has robust pre-commitment elements (trust gates, depletion management, speed matching) but no post-commitment emotional architecture. The Certainty Cascade (sequential micro-certainty deliveries after submission) and the Certainty Elation (acceptance as the 95%-to-100% qualitative shift) extend the library into post-commitment territory. This is a new emotional design category: what happens AFTER the user commits, and how do we protect the elevated reference point that commitment creates.

No existing library element addresses the negotiation phase. The library covers evaluation, onboarding, listing creation, and active lease, but the negotiation between host and guest (counter-offers, term adjustments) is a gap. works-006, communicates-002, looks-002, and behaves-004 collectively create a complete negotiation design framework grounded in Kahneman's loss-aversion-in-bargaining research. This is entirely new territory for the library.

extensions.extension_to: User segmentation based on psychological state
extensions.description: The library treats all users identically within their journey type (host or guest). behaves-005 introduces psychological-state segmentation: different flows for loss-state vs. stable-housing guests. This is a new design principle: the same platform, the same listings, but different interaction architectures based on the user's emotional and situational context. It extends the library from one-size-fits-all guest flows to psychologically adaptive flows.

emotional_arc_check.arc_description: The emotional arc of this run follows Kahneman's Prospect Theory structure: Loss-State Entry -> Reference Anchoring -> Endowment Acceleration -> Vulnerability Defusal -> Certainty Elation -> Satisfaction Protection

discovery.note: The discovery emotion (relief) correctly maps to the loss-state entry. A loss-state guest needs recognition before aspiration.

search.note: The reference-point comparison (behaves-001) transitions the guest from relief (someone understands my situation) to interest (this is cheaper than my current option). The emotional transition is smooth because the comparison validates rather than sells.

listing_evaluation.note: The Plan Your Stay configurator and ownership anticipation create progressive mental ownership. The emotion builds from interest to anticipation as the guest configures 'their' space.

proposal_creation.note: Confidence defuses the vulnerability of commitment. The certainty strip, social proof normalization, and Certainty Cascade create an emotional scaffolding around the Submit button.

negotiation.note: The preserved-first counter-offer display and gain-framed acceptance create reassurance by showing what was preserved before what changed. The emotional risk (loss aversion) is neutralized by framing.

acceptance.note: The 95%-to-100% certainty moment is the emotional peak of the journey. The design correctly treats this as the highest-stakes emotional moment and protects it from dilution.

move_in.note: The Certainty Timeline converts move-in anxiety into structured anticipation. Each completed step delivers a micro-certainty that prevents the guest's elevated reference point from being undermined.

active_lease.note: The savings reinforcement loop and proactive shield maintain satisfaction through continuous positive reinforcement and valley prevention. The endowment effect protects retention.

emotional_arc_check.arc_coherence: The emotional arc is coherent. Each phase's target emotion is a natural progression from the previous phase, and the transition mechanisms (comparison module, configurator, certainty cascade, savings loop) create smooth emotional bridges. The arc follows Kahneman's Prospect Theory prediction: loss-state entry (risk-seeking) -> gain framing (risk-averse within gains) -> endowment lock-in (loss-averse about owned arrangement) -> certainty capture (100% certainty at acceptance) -> loss prevention (protecting the elevated reference). No phase creates an emotional contradiction with adjacent phases.

discovery.coverage_assessment: Medium. Discovery has emotional and interaction coverage but lacks dedicated visual and information architecture elements. The identity-mirroring copy (feels-001) needs a corresponding visual pattern (L3) for the landing page. Recommend: future run should address discovery-specific visual design.

search.coverage_assessment: Strong. Search has coverage across all layers with strong coherence between the gain-frame price architecture (L2), the visual price display (L3), and the reference capture interaction (L4).

listing_evaluation.coverage_assessment: Very strong. Listing evaluation is the most comprehensively covered phase with elements addressing price comparison, mental ownership, protection, and emotional anticipation.

proposal_creation.coverage_assessment: Very strong. Proposal creation has the richest layer coverage, reflecting its status as the highest-risk commitment point.

negotiation.coverage_assessment: Strong across L1-L4 but missing a dedicated L5 emotional element. The negotiation phase's emotional dimension (reassurance after counter-offer) is implicitly handled by behaves-004's framing but would benefit from explicit emotional design in a future run.

acceptance.coverage_assessment: Very strong. Full coverage across all layers. The certainty theme is consistent and coherent from process (L1) through visual (L3) through interaction (L4) through emotion (L5).

move_in.coverage_assessment: Strong. Same certainty-focused elements as acceptance, which is correct -- the move-in phase is the physical realization of acceptance. However, move-in has unique logistical challenges (key handoff, first impression of physical space) that are not addressed by dedicated elements. Recommend: future run should address move-in logistics interaction design.

active_lease.coverage_assessment: Strong. Full coverage with a clear focus on loss prevention, savings reinforcement, and endowment protection. The active lease is well-served by this run's Prospect Theory lens.

loop_back_recommendations.recommendation: The reference-point capture mechanism should be integrated with the loss-state funnel (behaves-005). When a loss-state guest identifies themselves as 'between places' or 'using hotels/Sonder,' the platform should automatically suggest a reference point based on their selection (e.g., 'Sonder: $90/night' for hotel users, '$0 but no privacy' for friend-couch users). This eliminates the extra step of separately capturing the reference point for the segment most likely to convert.

The certainty timeline should include a 'host contact' step that fires 48 hours before move-in: 'Your host Sarah sent you a message: Welcome! Here is your check-in info.' This pre-establishes the host-guest relationship before the physical meeting, reducing the rare-event anxiety of meeting a stranger. The timeline currently covers documents, payment, and instructions but does not explicitly address the human connection that Steve would value.

The gain badge should adapt its comparison target based on the guest's reference. If the guest's reference is Sonder ($90/night), the badge shows 'Save $120/month vs. Sonder.' If the reference is hotels ($170/night), the badge shows 'Save $1,080/month vs. hotels.' If the reference is free (friend's couch), the badge should switch from savings to value: 'Your own space for $960/month.' This adaptive framing was implicit in the design but should be explicitly specified in the visual pattern.

The configurator should pre-fill with the most common stay pattern for the guest's segment. For between-places guests: 3 nights/week, 8 weeks. For hotel-replacers: 2-3 nights/week, 12 weeks. For stable-lease satellite seekers: 2 nights/week, 16 weeks. Smart defaults reduce configuration friction and accelerate mental ownership by showing the guest an arrangement that already looks right.

The acceptance moment should include a forward-projection element: 'Over the next 10 weeks, you will save approximately $1,200 vs. Sonder and have a consistent space in Cambridge.' This extends the certainty from 'I have a space right now' to 'I have a space for the foreseeable future,' which strengthens the endowment effect by giving the guest a longer mental ownership horizon.
